metadata.h1: How I Made An Intelligent Job Search Web App
metadata.description: Anyone who has looked for a job can tell you that it is hard work. Searching for relevant positions, updating your resume and Linkedin, applying for jobs, writing cover letters, and interviewing take…

all_paragraphs: Anyone who has looked for a job can tell you that it is hard work. Searching for relevant positions, updating your resume and Linkedin, applying for jobs, writing cover letters, and interviewing take a large amount of time and effort to complete. A common saying I always hear is: “Job searching is a full-time job.”

One of the most time-consuming and draining aspects of the job hunt is finding relevant job postings. This often entails frequenting online job boards, scanning for relevant job titles, reading the job’s description, and identifying whether or not this job posting is relevant to your qualifications. Because much of this data is available online, this task is ripe for some automation.

Find Me A Developer Job is a web app designed to search through online job boards and determine which job postings are most relevant to the specific applicant based on their provided resume. Relevancy is determined with a similarity score which identifies how similar the resume is to the job posting.

This app is a simple, barebones proof-of-concept that will be continually added to and changed. Currently, the app only searches through the Github job board and is tailored for applicants searching for developer jobs.
Because of the low number of jobs posted on Github, this tool is not very useful for an exhaustive job search. However, as additional job boards have added this value will increase.
This app also currently uses a simple similarity algorithm. There is tons of room for improvement in this algorithm and will be a key feature for future improvements.

Find Me A Developer Job was developed using Python with the Streamlit package. Streamlit is an amazing python package that allows you to quickly and easily create web apps — especially machine learning tools. If you are a data scientist at heart and not a web designer like me, I highly recommend checking out Streamlit here.
In addition to Streamlit, pandas and numpy was used for data processing, requests for API calls, JSON for parsing the api returns, and difflib for the similarity algorithm.
There are three main components to the web application: user interface (aka frontend), web server (aka backend), and the API server.

The user interface (seen below) prompts the user to input a location, search term, and the text of their resume. These three inputs will then be passed to the server backend. Both location and search terms are optional parameters, however, not providing a resume will cause the application to select a random job since it does not have any similarity scores to rank on.

After receiving the location, search term, and resume the server will construct an HTTP call to the Github job board API. The call is constructed with the location and search term parameters. The API will then return a JSON string containing the jobs that meet the parameters. The JSON string is read in using the JSON library and converted to a pandas data frame for processing. The server then compares each job’s description to the resume and calculates a similarity score. The job with the largest similarity score is then passed to the user interface, displaying the job title, description, and application method (seen below).

Creating a local web app in Streamlit is great, however, allowing others to easily access the application is important. In order to let people access the tool through my website, I deployed the application to a free Heroku server. In order to do this, four files were required: the application itself, a setup file, a Procfile, and a requirements file.
The setup file is a sh file that contains instructions for the webserver. The setup file I used is shown below.
The Procfile declares what processes should be run. My Procfile is shown below.
The requirements file is a text file that declares what python packages are needed on the server to run your application. My requirements file is shown below.

Find Me A Developer Job is very much a barebones proof-of-concept. While I hope to take this project further and start to provide more value with the tool, Python and Streamlit were indispensable in allowing me to quickly get a prototype up and running to gather feedback and make iterative improvements. If you would like to test out the application I would graciously accept any feedback you have!
